swerve

Class SwerveWheel

  • java.lang.Object
    • SubsystemBase
      • swerve.SwerveWheel

  • public abstract class SwerveWheel
extends SubsystemBase
    An abstract class used by SwerveDrive to represent a module. Each SwerveWheel contains a wheel which can steer in any direction and drive forwards or backwards. Note: Based on encoder functionality, the wheel should be facing directly forwards when this subsystem is instantiated, or resetSteerEncoder() should be used along with a homing sequence.

    • Constructor Summary

      SwerveWheel()

      Gets the wheel's steering direction in revolutions, starting with 0 = directly forwards and increasing as the wheel steers clockwise (from a top-down point of view).

      Gets the drive encoder difference from the last drive encoder reset, converted into inches traveled along the ground.
      abstract void resetDriveEncoder()
      Resets the drive encoder to a value of zero.
      abstract void resetSteerEncoder()
      Resets the steering encoder to a value of zero.

      Sets the drive speed of the wheel on the interval [-1, 1].

      Sets the drive speed of the wheel, along with the target steering direction of the module.
      void stop()

    • Constructor Detail

      • SwerveWheel

        public SwerveWheel()

    • Method Detail

      • getDirection

        public abstract double getDirection()
        Gets the wheel's steering direction in revolutions, starting with 0 = directly forwards and increasing as the wheel steers clockwise (from a top-down point of view). The output should not be trimmed to stay within a certain range (i.e. an output of 1.2 revolutions should not be looped around to the equivalent angle 0.2 revolutions).
        Returns:
        The wheel's steering direction

      • setDirection

        public abstract void setDirection(double targetDirection)
        Sets the target steering direction of the wheel, using the same rotational measurement as getDirection(). This means that if you were to pass 1.2 revolutions as an argument, the input should not wrap to the equivalent angle of 0.2 revolutions, and the module should instead perform whatever steering action is necessary in order to make the output of getDirection() closer to 1.2.
        Parameters:
        targetDirection - The target steering direction
        See Also:
        steerAndDrive(double, double), setDriveSpeed(double)

      • setDriveSpeed

        public abstract void setDriveSpeed(double speed)
        Sets the drive speed of the wheel on the interval [-1, 1].
        Parameters:
        speed - The drive speed
        See Also:
        steerAndDrive(double, double), setDirection(double)

      • stopSteering

        public abstract void stopSteering()
        Immediately stops all steering movement.

      • resetSteerEncoder

        public abstract void resetSteerEncoder()
        Resets the steering encoder to a value of zero. This should only be used when it is certain that the wheel is facing directly forward (i.e. the encoders are properly set up such that getDirection() will return the correct steering direction when called).

      • resetDriveEncoder

        public abstract void resetDriveEncoder()
        Resets the drive encoder to a value of zero. This can be used to set a reference point for determining the distance traveled over a period of time.
        See Also:
        getPositionDifference()

      • getPositionDifference

        public abstract double getPositionDifference()
        Gets the drive encoder difference from the last drive encoder reset, converted into inches traveled along the ground.
        Returns:
        The inches traveled since the last resetDriveEncoder() call

      • steerAndDrive

        public final void steerAndDrive(double targetDirection,
                                double speed)
        Sets the drive speed of the wheel, along with the target steering direction of the module. The drive speed of the wheel should be on the interval [-1, 1], and the target steering direction should be on the interval [0, 360). A target steering direction of 0 degrees should correspond with moving directly forward, where an increase in target steering direction corresponds with a clockwise movement in target steering direction (from a top-down point of view).
        Parameters:
        targetDirection - The target steering direction, as specified above
        speed - The drive speed of the wheel
        See Also:
        setDriveSpeed(double), setDirection(double)

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops all movement.
